title: Are cars faster today than they were in the 1980s? - Quora

response.answer_text: Cars accelerate today at rates faster than ever before. A 1980s economy car would take 13 seconds to get you from 0 to 60 miles per hour. Today, that is considered unacceptable, and 10 seconds is slow. Economy cars of the 1980s typically made 70 horsepower. Today’s make double that, easily. What about sports cars? Let’s compare the Corvette. The 1984 Corvette came with a 205 horsepower engine moving 3200 pounds. That was good for a brisk sub-7 second 0–60 time, and a top speed of 140 miles per hour. The last front-engined Corvette came standard with a 455 horsepower engine, giving 0–60 mph in just 3.8 seconds. The ZR-1 was even more impressive, with 755 horsepower pushing a car just 350 pounds heavier than the 1984 Corvette, giving a top speed of 219 miles per hour. Okay, you might say, but not everyone can afford a Corvette, how about family cars. Let’s take Fords, for example. The Fairmont started off the 1980s strong, with a 137 horsepower 5 litre V8 giving quick 9.7 second 0–60 times, but not-as-good fuel economy. The modern Ford Taurus gives 7 second 0–60 times, but better fuel economy than the 4-cylinder engine (the Pinto’s 2.3-litre inline 4) could have attained.

response.answer_text: Very much so. Cars were lighter in the 80s by quite a bit, but high horsepower was 150. Most smaller cars were under 100 hp. The end of the 80s started seeing modern engine evolution, but it really was t till the mid 90s that we started seeing faster cars. japanese cars in the 80s struggled at the speed limit. Not just because they weren’t particularly powerful, but they were engineered poorly. They were largely ported over from Japanese market where speed limits are more around 45mph. They would shake and vibrate at 55–60. People don’t even remember down shifting for hills anymore. I remember having to down shift for hills in my “sports car” celicas and Supras. I couldn’t hold 60 up a highway with any sort of grade. Most cars couldn’t without a downshift or being particularly powerful American highway machines.

Very much so. I’d guess the average car has nearly two times the power the same model had in the early 80s. The V8 Mustang was around 225 and now it’s around 460 with better mileage. A 1985 Civic was 91hp, and a 2020 is 205.

Yes. I currently own a 1988 Jaguar XJ-S. This was one of the faster cars you could buy at that time. I’m told it should be able to do 140 mph on top end, but I haven’t had it over 125. 0–60 is in the ballpark of 8 seconds. Plenty of vanilla family cars will beat it to 60 these days.

A 1957 Ford “Battle Bird” was clocked at over 200 mph back then. With a “Blown” 312 Y block V8. After the EPA “Screwed” all engines, horsepower was a “Thing of the past”. Unless you “Built it yourself”. Yes a Cadillac CTS-V and a Corvette can exceed 200 mph today. So we have “Caught Up” with the 1950’s in “Top Speed”.

Yes, but not as much as you think! However, todays cars are more powerful, more economical and much safer! So one can drive faster without being quicker than cars of a generation ago.Top speeds arent much higher.
